item.title: String of both Arrays
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“my-swagger, post:29, topic:552223”]C++ rather towards a constant char array so it doesn’t fully understand the notion of a string.

Am I wrong about Java?

Edit:
Okay t4 you got me! I looked up how Java handles it in the background and the concept is pretty much the same. It’s efficiently dealt with though, which is good.[/quote]
both std::string (C++) and java.lang.String (Java) are just class wrappers over a heap allocated character array as well

Read full topic

@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“Zymus, post:24, topic:552223”][quote author=my-swagger link=topic=671139.msg4488293#msg4488293 date=1435701926]
It’s only right for Java to allow switch statements with Strings because it does have good support for Strings unlike languages such as C++ that don’t support String’s as a type.

Java is doing good with it’s life
[/quote]

I think they took a step in the wrong direction with lambdas, but that’s a story for another day; not that Java shouldn’t have lambdas, but it could have been implemented better.[/quote]

god I love lambdas and streams

item.title: String of both Arrays
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“my-swagger, post:23, topic:552223”]It’s only right for Java to allow switch statements with Strings because it does have good support for Strings unlike languages such as C++ that don’t support String’s as a type.

Java is doing good with it’s life[/quote]
What the fudge are you talking about?

While you can’t use std::string in a switch statement (you need to convert them to an integral hash value first and optionally second-check with a O(n) iteration over the string itself depending on the collision chance), it is most certainly a standard type. BTW, the aforementioned switch implementation is EXACTLY how Java does it. Your switch statements are really the complexity of the hash algorithm + O(n) equality check.

Read full topic

item.title: String of both Arrays
item.dc:creator: @EcoPS_GM EcoPS GM
item.description:
@EcoPS_GM wrote:

[quote=“Zymus, post:24, topic:552223”]not that Java shouldn’t have lambdas, but it could have been implemented better.[/quote]I was about to say…

[quote=“lawl, post:25, topic:552223”][quote author=Zymus link=topic=671139.msg4488299#msg4488299 date=1435702494]

It’s only right for Java to allow switch statements with Strings because it does have good support for Strings unlike languages such as C++ that don’t support String’s as a type.

Java is doing good with it’s life

I think they took a step in the wrong direction with lambdas, but that’s a story for another day; not that Java shouldn’t have lambdas, but it could have been implemented better.
[/quote]
I actually think they did a really good job with lambdas considering they added it in 20 years after the language’s inception without breaking backwards compatibility. What don’t you like about it?[/quote]Well one thing I don’t like about it - in Java 6 & 7, the traditional way to iterate over a list of elements [typically strings] would be to map their lengths. As of now, it’s becoming significantly similar to Scala. Take a look at the following:

val example = names.map(name => check(name.length))
With this - you’d receive a pretty long debugging that’s quite difficult to understand. Notwithstanding, I understand that this is extremely basic, and working with everyday utilities with more complex structures - you’d receive the same principle of the debugging. Until JDK 8, Java developers seemed to be astray from this. However, when you use this with the wonderful use of implementation of Java 8’s lambdas:

Stream example = names.stream().map(name -> check(name));
You would receive something very similar to the Scala debugging. Notice how the code itself is actually quite similar to Scala as well? We’re paying the price for efficiency.

Read full topic
